title: Assessment of Harmful Emissions from Multiple Binder Systems in Pilot-Scale Sand Casting
reasoning: The abstract explicitly states that inorganic binders (sodium silicate and geopolymer) achieved over 90% reductions in BTEX compounds, including ethylbenzene, compared to organic systems. This indicates a clear safety advantage in terms of lower hazardous emissions, supporting these inorganic binders as safer alternatives to ethylbenzene-containing organic binders in foundry applications.

title: Impact of Aromatic Hydrocarbons on Emissions in a Custom-Built High-Pressure Combustor
reasoning: The abstract compares emissions from ethylbenzene and other aromatic hydrocarbons, noting that ethylbenzene produced the highest unburned hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide emissions, while Indane exhibited the lowest levels of these pollutants, suggesting more complete combustion. This implies that Indane may be a safer alternative to ethylbenzene in terms of emission-related safety.
CHEMICAL HARM: high unburned hydrocarbons (UHC) emissions, high carbon monoxide (CO) emissions

title: Influence of Biodiesel on Emissions of Criteria and Non-Criteria Primary and Secondary Pollutants
reasoning: The abstract discusses biodiesel as a suitable alternative fuel that reduces emissions of benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylenes (BTEX) compared to diesel. This indicates a safety advantage in terms of lower emissions of ethylbenzene when using biodiesel blends. Therefore, biodiesel can be reasonably interpreted as a safer alternative to ethylbenzene-containing diesel fuel.

title: Toxicity Threshold of Perfluorocarbon Liquids for Intraocular Use: Dose–Response Assessment of In Vitro Cytotoxicity of Possible Contaminants
reasoning: The abstract identifies ethylbenzene as one of the most cytotoxic impurities in perfluorooctane (PFO) used for vitreoretinal surgery. It also reports that two substances, 5H-PFO and perfluoro-2-butyltetrahydrofuran, were non-cytotoxic at the highest tested concentrations, implying they have lower cytotoxicity than ethylbenzene. This suggests these substances could be safer alternatives to ethylbenzene in this context.

title: Technical Evaluation of BTEX Emission Mitigation from Gas Dehydration Unit by Revamping and Using Alternative Glycols
reasoning: The abstract discusses using alternative glycols, specifically monoethylene glycol (MEG), as a strategy to reduce BTEX emissions including ethylbenzene during natural gas dehydration. It states that MEG is the best scenario in reducing BTEX emissions with efficient dew point control, implying a safety advantage by lowering harmful emissions compared to conventional methods involving ethylbenzene. Therefore, MEG is presented as a safer alternative to ethylbenzene in this context.
CHEMICAL HARM: catastrophic physical health problems, catastrophic mental health problems

title: dl‐Limonene as an Alternative Sustainable Solvent to Xylenes for the Industrial Preparation of Release Formulations
reasoning: The abstract identifies dl-limonene as an alternative to BTEX solvents, which include ethylbenzene, and mentions that the use of BTEX is discouraged due to their toxicological profile. It explicitly explores dl-limonene as a more sustainable solvent alternative, implying safety advantages over ethylbenzene. The dl-limonene/ethyl acetate mixture is presented as a suitable replacement solvent for industrial use.

title: Exhaust emissions of gaseous and particle size-segregated water-soluble organic compounds from diesel-biodiesel blends
reasoning: The abstract compares emissions from biodiesel blends to conventional diesel and explicitly states that adding biodiesel reduces emissions of ethylbenzene and other pollutants. This indicates that biodiesel blends are a safer alternative to conventional diesel fuels containing ethylbenzene due to lower emissions of harmful compounds.
